sub_topic: Finding eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a matrix using power iteration method
message_1:
Consider the matrix 

$$\begin{bmatrix} 4 & -1 & 1 \\ -1 & 3 & -2 \\ 1 & -2 & 3 \end{bmatrix}$$

Using the power iteration method, find the dominant eigenvalue and its corresponding eigenvector with an initial approximation vector of $\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$.
message_2:
The power iteration method is an iterative process used to find the dominant eigenvalue and its corresponding eigenvector of a matrix. The method starts with an initial approximation vector and iteratively multiplies it by the matrix until it converges to the dominant eigenvector. The dominant eigenvalue can then be found using the Rayleigh quotient.

Given the matrix $A$:

$$A = \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -1 & 1 \\ -1 & 3 & -2 \\ 1 & -2 & 3 \end{bmatrix}$$

And the initial approximation vector $x^{(0)}$:

$$x^{(0)} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

We will perform a few iterations of the power iteration method to find the dominant eigenvalue and its corresponding eigenvector.

1. First iteration:

$$x^{(1)} = Ax^{(0)} = \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -1 & 1 \\ -1 & 3 & -2 \\ 1 & -2 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 4 \\ 0 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}$$

Normalize $x^{(1)}$:

$$x^{(1)} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{20}} \begin{bmatrix} 4 \\ 0 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{2}{\sqrt{5}} \\ 0 \\ \frac{1}{\sqrt{5}} \end{bmatrix}$$

2. Second iteration:

$$x^{(2)} = Ax^{(1)} = \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -1 & 1 \\ -1 & 3 & -2 \\ 1 & -2 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \frac{2}{\sqrt{5}} \\ 0 \\ \frac{1}{\sqrt{5}} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{9}{\sqrt{5}} \\ -\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}} \\ \frac{5}{\sqrt{5}} \end{bmatrix}$$

Normalize $x^{(2)}$:

$$x^{(2)} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{107}} \begin{bmatrix} 9 \\ -1 \\ 5 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{9}{\sqrt{107}} \\ -\frac{1}{\sqrt{107}} \\ \frac{5}{\sqrt{107}} \end{bmatrix}$$

At this point, we can see that the eigenvector is converging. We can perform more iterations if needed, but for this example, we will stop here and calculate the dominant eigenvalue using the Rayleigh quotient:

$$\lambda = \frac{x^{(2)T}Ax^{(2)}}{x^{(2)T}x^{(2)}} = \frac{\begin{bmatrix} \frac{9}{\sqrt{107}} & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{107}} & \frac{5}{\sqrt{107}} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -1 & 1 \\ -1 & 3 & -2 \\ 1 & -2 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \frac{9}{\sqrt{107}} \\ -\frac{1}{\sqrt{107}} \\ \frac{5}{\sqrt{107}} \end{bmatrix}}{\begin{bmatrix} \frac{9}{\sqrt{107}} & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{107}} & \frac{5}{\sqrt{107}} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \frac{9}{\sqrt{107}} \\ -\frac{1}{\sqrt{107}} \\ \frac{5}{\sqrt{107}} \end{bmatrix}}$$

$$\lambda \approx 5.24$$

So, the dominant eigenvalue is approximately $\lambda \approx 5.24$, and its corresponding eigenvector is approximately:

$$x^{(2)} \approx \begin{bmatrix} \frac{9}{\sqrt{107}} \\ -\frac{1}{\sqrt{107}} \\ \frac{5}{\sqrt{107}} \end{bmatrix}$$
